body:
Hi!

That library requires Java 8. Gobblin runs on Java 7.

On Wed, Feb 3, 2016 at 8:01 AM, kadaan notifications@github.com wrote:

> @sahilTakiar https://github.com/sahilTakiar Have you guys looked at
> using parseq instead of ParallelRunner?
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/linkedin/gobblin/pull/572#issuecomment-179311940.
LGTM.

@kadaan this is meant as more of a temp fix for https://github.com/linkedin/gobblin/issues/561 I agree it is not going to address all the issues for S3 publishing, but I just want to get this in so that it doesn't cause any data loss for any other users.
@tuGithub comments addressed, PR updated

LGTM.
@kadaan I agree this won't work for exactly-once on S3. Something like #572 is still needed.
@zliu41 I'd still like to get #572 in.  It will take me a bit longer due to the changes from #569.
@kadaan yes, lets still work on #572 although since this is such a big change, we may want to have a design doc outlining the changes. @chavdar what do you think?

@zliu41 Am I correct in believing that this implementation requires that the pending upload files be stored on a shared filesystem such as S3 or HDFS?  If so, this should be called out.  Additionally, we should detect use of LocalFileSystem and fail to start.
Haven't really look at ParSeq before, it seems version 1.4.2 is Java 7 compatible though. Or we can make a placeholder JIRA for ParSeq integration when Gobblin Java 8 migration is done.

Hey @sahilTakiar, I'm just running some end-to-end tests once more on the latest changes with some adverse situations (connections being cut unexpectedly, the proxy dying halfway through, etc.) to ensure these are handled cleanly. Will ping as soon as I'm done.
@sahilTakiar can you review?
Can you rebase your commit, I believe https://github.com/linkedin/gobblin/pull/661 may be trying to do something similar
LGTM!
LGTM!
@sahilTakiar thank you for the review!
@sahilTakiar thank you for the review!

@ibuenros I just changed this class to deal with the issue i reported last night. I apologize if you saw the bug and started working on a fix in parallel to mine.  I'd welcome any suggestions on how to report and fix issues without causing duplicate work.  For my part, I will indicate in a bug that I intend to fix it.
@kadaan @sahilTakiar Thanks for pointing that out. I changed the PR to include those changes. This PR is adding logging for those exceptions and still including fail policies.
@kadaan added documentation on the policies.
LGTM
LGTM
I went ahead and updated the wiki page you mentioned.
Thank you for the review!
LGTM
@pcadabam can you review when you get a chance?
@tuGithub PR updated
LGTM
@ibuenros any more comments?
Couple comments, LGTM otherwise.

@sahilTakiar @ydai1124 @cwsteinbach updated 99035f7

Main changes:
- Use a pool of `HiveMetaStoreClient`s instead of a single `HiveMetaStoreClient`, because `HiveMetaStoreClient` doesn't seem to support concurrent requests.
- Added a striped lock class (`HiveStripedLocks`) as suggested by @cwsteinbach 
- When creating a table/partition, if the table/partition already exists, it checks whether the table or partition needs to be altered (`needToUpdateTable` and `needToUpdatePartition`). For example, update is needed if there's a schema change. If so it alters the table or partition.
- Addressed other comments.
Trivial changes, self-approving.
@ydai1124 Can you review?
LGTM. Is this part of the change to make dataset more generic?
No, this is a fix to the fact that `ConfigurableGlobDatasetFinder` got made abstract a while back, so now there is no simple, configurable dataset finder for cleaner job.
@pcadabam addressed comments.
@liyinan926 Can you review this?
@sahilTakiar I think this broke Task publishing as detailed in #675
Sure, I will take a look at a later time today.
Can you please explain what the race is?
@sahilTakiar Can you review this?
@chavdar see https://jira01.corp.linkedin.com:8443/browse/ETL-4046

@zliu41 @chavdar We have seen a similar race which was causing our yarn gobblin jobs to fail.  What it looked like was the TaskStateCollectorService was trying to read a sequence file that had not been completely written.  We added retries to the deserialize and that seemed to fix it.  I haven't yet been able to completely verify the fix so I haven't created a PR for it.

@zliu41 Can you share the pertinent info for those of us who can't access jira?
@zliu41 That is exactly the problem we were seeing.  We added a retry with backoffs when deserializing the state.
LGTM
@sahilTakiar @ydai1124 updated 7855bf7
LGTM
A few more minor comments, overall it looks good.
LGTM
@liyinan926 Addressed your comments.  BTW, I think if we can really beef up the lifecycle events, that it will simplify AbstractJobLauncher and allow gobblin to have much more flexibility.

@chavdar , @sahilTakiar 

please review it when you have time
Grrrr.  Intermittently failing tests!!!!!!
@abti @chavdar @ibuenros: Can one of you please review this?
LGTM
Trivial changes. Self approving.
LGTM
@sahilTakiar @ydai1124 can you review?
@ibuenros updated f574fa8
LGTM. Merged
LGTM, will wait for travis to finish before merge
Pending Pradhan's comment, the changes to the `SimpleHDFSConfigStore` LGTM.

I really have no experience here, but from what I read there are some downsides to submodule linking.  That said, either way submodule/subtree have specific steps that need to be done to keep things in sync.  Should those steps be detailed somewhere?
I've also heard bad things regarding submodules. I'll wait for someone more familiar with this stuff to confirm if this is the right approach.
Talked to Ziyang. LGTM.
Check out this writeup: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6941688/how-to-integrate-a-github-wiki-into-the-main-project
LGTM
@ibuenros @abti Can you please review this?

@sahilTakiar 

Please review with the updated version
These seem like unrelated failures, but it is really had to tell because the the test results are not saved anywhere.
@kadaan if the build passes on your system for all 4 combinations (java 7 and 8, hadoop 1 and 2), then that's enough. We're trying to figure out an alternative to Travis, but it may take some time.
@ibuenros Let me check all 4 and verify.  Travis is fine with me, but the intermittent failures really suck!!!
Any other comments @ibuenros ?

@ibuenros Crud.  I don't think I can verify locally due some tests that always seem to fail locally.  For instance:

@ibuenros Do these work for you locally?  Is there something I'm missing on my machine for this to work?  What OS are you running locally?  OS X?
What setup produced that failure? The tests pass fine with hadoop 1 and java 8 on my system (OS X mavericks). Can you get a pass with the head of master?

@ibuenros Crud.  I think those test failures are due to the Qubole hadoop2 libraries.  When I don't use the Qubole hadoop libraries, the following runs all work locally:
- `./gradlew clean check -PskipTestGroup=disabledOnTravis -info -Dorg.gradle.java.home=/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.8.0_45.jdk/Contents/Home`
- `./gradlew clean check -PskipTestGroup=disabledOnTravis -info -Dorg.gradle.java.home=/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.7.0_80.jdk/Contents/Home/`
- `./gradlew clean check -PuseHadoop2 -PskipTestGroup=disabledOnTravis -info -Dorg.gradle.java.home=/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.8.0_45.jdk/Contents/Home`
- `./gradlew clean check -PuseHadoop2 -PskipTestGroup=disabledOnTravis -info -Dorg.gradle.java.home=/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.7.0_80.jdk/Contents/Home/`
Can you resolve the merge conflicts?

One thing I would like to point out is that it would be nice to come up with a rich set of lifecycle events which can be used to perform functionality such as this.  That way every feature doesn't need to involve changes to AbstractJobLauncher, JobContext, etc.  Additionally, it would mean that users of gobblin could create functionality like this without having to modify gobblin.  As a simple example look at: #674.  The events added here have allowed us to get exactly once semantics for task based publishing (before you guys release your real solution for this).

If we were to store the documentation within the gobblin repo, it would be nice to have the official documentation created with sphinx (we could use pandoc http://pandoc.org to convert from the current markdown files to reStructuredText files).  Hosting the documentation could be done on Read the Docs (ex. https://readthedocs.org/projects/airflow/).  Read the Docs can be triggered by git commits, supports multiple versions based on tags or branches, etc.

Yes the observer pattern could be a good fit here if there are multiple events that need to be triggered by something. However Hive registration is not merely some independent observer here; it is a critical step (similar as publishing data) that needs to succeed before the dataset state can be persisted (otherwise the registration will be lost).
LGTM
just one comment, LGTM otherwise @kadaan what do you think of this approach?
LGTM

Overall, looks good.  

That said, I worry about the proliferation of code that handles incompatibilities with hadoop filesystem implementations.  I think going forward it might be nice to have our own filesystem interface with which we can enforce stricter guarantees.  For instance we could require that an implementor if the interface indicate whether specific operations are atomic and take the appropriate action.  Or we could require that implementors make all operations atomic (though we have no way to enforce this).
@liyinan926 You mind chiming in?
Whoops, hadn't noticed the conflicts, sorry. Merged and pushed.

I understand your point, but I don't think having our own interface is the correct solution: we would have to manually extend all implementations of hadoop's `FileSystem`, and it would be harder for users to benefit from already existing implementations.
Maybe we could have a `FileSystem` decorator instead with a few of the methods you mention. We could then detect certain known schemes with incompatibilities and apply fixes across the entire code, but any `FileSystem` we haven't considered yet would still work appropriately.
@liyinan926 Addressed comments.  NOTE: I made the same change the ParallelRunner because their implementation of `close` is largely the same.
That would be great, but I think users of gobblin should be able to provide new decorators without having to extend gobblin itself.
I think it's ok to merge and I agree we should de-dup task properties that are already in job properties, which can be in a separate PR.
@ydai1124 can you review? Thanks.

@liyinan926 I will provide a PR for the de-dupe.  

Also, I find that saving history is extremely slow.  I was looking into replacing all the EXISTS->INSERT/UPDATE code with an UPSERT.  To do this, I believe the indexes on the metric and property tables would need to change.  In my local tests, it seems much faster.  Additionally, I was looking at making the insert of metrics/property be done in batches of up to 1000.  What do you think?
LGTM
Created a follow up ticket to avoid having to do this in the future https://github.com/linkedin/gobblin/issues/693
BTW, do you guys use the history store in prod?
Why does `JobContext` need to change? Why can't `BaseDataPublisherWithHiveRegistration` simply do the hive registration.

When publishing data in tasks, each mapper uses a publisher to publish its own data. I want to avoid creating 200+ connections to HiveMetaStore. Also, different mappers may publish to the same path so these paths will be registered multiple times.
Everything LGTM, but I don't understand what `getImportsRecursivelyIncludePhantomFromCache` is for can you add a more detailed explanation?
Trivial change, self-approving.
How does work with exactly once semantics?
